Robert Saleh plans to call defensive plays with Tennessee Titans
description: Incoming Tennessee Titans head coach Robert Saleh intends to call defensive plays in 2026, something he did not do with the New York Jets.
fullText:
Robert Saleh‚Äôs impending tenure as Tennessee Titans head coach comes with an unusual wrinkle for the franchise: He plans to call defensive plays himself, a responsibility he did not carry as head coach of the New York Jets.

New #Titans HC Robert Saleh indicated to teams in interviews that he plans to call defensive plays in his next stop as HC, per sources. 

That wasn‚Äôt the case in his #Jets tenure. https://t.co/9hjhYCjkh7 pic.twitter.com/TtdMqrn1AA

‚Äî Jordan Schultz (@Schultz_Report) January 20, 2026

Saleh‚Äôs decision to take on defensive play-calling signals that he wants more direct control of the side of the ball that has defined his career. As San Francisco‚Äôs defensive coordinator, Saleh built a reputation as a top defensive mind, and Tennessee clearly hopes to lean on that expertise to upgrade a defense that struggled with consistency last season.

But Saleh‚Äôs choice also raises the stakes on his offensive coordinator hire.

With Saleh focused on defense, Tennessee must land a top-tier offensive play-caller -- not only to manage game strategy but to help develop rookie quarterback Cam Ward, the 2025 No. 1 overall pick.

Ward showed promise as a rookie, but his continued growth likely hinges on having an OC who can design and call an effective offense. Saleh‚Äôs expanded role gives him control where he‚Äôs strongest, but success in Nashville will depend on pairing that with elite offensive leadership.

This article originally appeared on Titans Wire: Robert Saleh plans to call defensive plays with Tennessee Titans

title: New York Giants' John Harbaugh addresses Todd Monken as possible OC
description: New York Giants head coach John Harbaugh would like to add Todd Monken as offensive coordinator but admits there's much uncertainty.
fullText:
New York Giants head coach John Harbaugh is wasting no time reshaping his coaching staff ahead of his official introduction on Tuesday.

While reports earlier this month indicated that former Baltimore Ravens offensive coordinator Todd Monken was expected to follow Harbaugh to East Rutherford -- pending Rooney Rule interviews for the position -- the situation has grown uncertain.

Speaking to the New York Post on Monday, Harbaugh remained cautious about Monken's potential role as offensive coordinator.

"We'll see, can‚Äôt really say right now, there's a lot of moving parts," Harbaugh said. "He's interviewing [Tuesday] for the Browns head coaching job, so there's a lot of balls still up in the NFL, that's for sure. Look at today, man. Crazy."

Harbaugh plans to meet with members of Brian Daboll‚Äôs former staff this week to evaluate possible retentions, though significant changes are anticipated.

The Giants have also requested permission to interview Vikings passing game coordinator Daronte Jones for their defensive coordinator vacancy.

This article originally appeared on Giants Wire: New York Giants' John Harbaugh addresses Todd Monken as possible OC

title: Justice Department asks federal judge to deny special master for Epstein files
description: (This Jan 17 story has been repeated with no changes to text) NEW YORK, Jan 17 (Reuters) - The U.S.
fullText:
(This Jan 17 story has been repeated with no changes to text)

NEW YORK, Jan 17 (Reuters) - The U.S. Justice Department has asked a New ‚ÄãYork federal judge to deny a request by two lawmakers seeking an appointment ‚Äåof a special master to monitor the public release of records tied to the late financier and ‚Äåconvicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

The Justice Department since December has been releasing caches of documents tied to its investigations of Epstein. But U.S. Representatives Ro Khanna and Thomas Massie have criticized the department's slow pace.

Khanna, a California Democrat, and Massie, a Kentucky Republican, last week ‚Å†said they asked U.S. District ‚ÄåJudge Paul Engelmayer to permit them to file a brief that would argue for the appointment of a special master and independent ‚Äçmonitor, given the Justice Department's failure to fully comply with a law that requires the DOJ to release all records related to Epstein by December 19.

In a six-page letter filed on Friday ‚Äãto U.S. District Court Judge Paul Engelmayer on Friday, U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi ‚Äåand Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche argued that Khanna and Thomas Massie are not parties to the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case involving Epstein and should not be allowed to file a friend of the court request in the matter.

"Representatives Khanna and Massie do not have standing, their stated objectives are in-consistent with the role of an amicus ‚Å†as well as the role of the Court, ‚Äãand, in any event, there is no authority ‚Äãpermitting the Court to grant the Representatives the relief they improperly seek," the DOJ said in the letter signed by Jay Clayton, US attorney ‚Äçfor the Southern District ‚Å†of New York.

Maxwell is serving a 20-year prison sentence for helping Epstein sexually abuse underage girls.

The Justice Department said at the end of 2025 that it had ‚Å†5.2 million pages of Epstein files left to review and needs 400 lawyers from four different department ‚Äåoffices to help with the process through late January.

title: Is Jim O'Neil emerging as Jets' defensive coordinator favorite?
description: Is Detroit Lions defensive assistant Jim O'Neil emerging as the New York Jets' favorite DC candidate?
fullText:
The New York Jets announced they have interviewed eight candidates to fill their defensive coordinator vacancy. Head coach Aaron Glenn will soon make a decision to appoint Steve Wilks' successor. Among the options, Detroit Lions assistant Jim O'Neil could emerge as the favorite.

O'Neil has two advantages working in his favor. He's the only candidate on the list to possess previous experience with Coach Glenn. He's also just one of two candidates, alongside Wink Martindale, to have previously coordinated a defense in the NFL.

Let's break them down into 2 categories:

Worked previously with Aaron Glenn: Jim O'Neil (current Lions def asst/safeties coach)

Previous NFL DC experience: O'Neil (Cle, SF), Wink Martindale (Balt, NYG). Glenn spoke to Martindale a couple of weeks ago.

Leonhard (Den pass game‚Ä¶ https://t.co/1CsSGfPY38

‚Äî Rich Cimini (@RichCimini) January 16, 2026

O'Neil was a defensive assistant under Glenn with the Detroit Lions in 2024. He also knows the Jets and AFC East well. O'Neil actually worked for the Jets from 2009-2012 under Rex Ryan, and later worked for the Buffalo Bills in 2013.

O'Neil then coordinated the Cleveland Browns' defense in 2014-15, and then again for the San Francisco 49ers in 2016. The Browns fielded a top-10 scoring defense under O'Neil in 2014, but regressed to 29th in 2015. His 49ers defense in 2016 was the worst in the league, allowing 30 points per contest.

The Jets have a mixture of intriguing candidates. Ranging from veterans like O'Neil and Martindale to Jim Leonhard and DeMarcus Covington, Glenn has a decision to make. Glenn's familiarity with O'Neil could play a role.

This article originally appeared on Jets Wire: Is Jim O'Neil emerging as Jets' defensive coordinator favorite?

title: John Harbaugh effect: NY Giants‚Äô over/under for 2026 season at 8.5
description: That is more games than the Giants have won in the last two seasons combined.
fullText:
Yes, expectations for the New York Giants have undoubtedly been raised by the hiring of John Harbaugh as head coach. The betting markets are absolutely a reflection of that.

Betonline.ag has the Giants‚Äô over/under win total set at 8.5 victories for the 2026 season. The Giants have gone just 7-27 the past two seasons, and 13-38 over the past three.

Harbaugh‚Äôs teams with the Baltimore Ravens made the playoffs in 12 of his 18 seasons.

We don‚Äôt yet know game dates and times, but we do know who the Giants‚Äô opponents will be in 2026.

With that schedule in mid, would you take the over or the under?

title: Trump‚Äôs BFF Kim Jong Un Is Panicking After Decapitation Drama
description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is getting the message: He‚Äôs vulnerable to the same quick hit that President Trump ordered to pluck Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro from power and toss him into custody in New York. The brazen Jan. 3 raid on Caracas by U.S. forces almost certainly struck more fear into the potbellied dictator than any military drills or aerial shows of force ever could.
fullText:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is getting the message: He‚Äôs vulnerable to the same quick hit that President Trump ordered to pluck Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro from power and toss him into custody in New York.

The brazen Jan. 3 raid on Caracas by U.S. forces almost certainly struck more fear into the potbellied dictator than any military drills or aerial shows of force ever could. In doing so, it‚Äôs also ramped up the risks of a potential nuclear showdown as Kim goes into panic mode, triggered by the same American president who has routinely boasted of the pair‚Äôs ‚Äúvery good relationship.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe operation to ‚Äòrendition‚Äô the president of Venezuela demonstrates the capabilities that have to be of concern to North Korea,‚Äù says Sydney Seiler, former national intelligence officer for North Korea at the National Intelligence Council. The word ‚Äúrendition,‚Äù as used by Seiler, is CIA-speak for capturing an enemy operative and sending him elsewhere for prosecution, or even torture and killing.

The other key word is ‚Äúdecapitation,‚Äù which Kim is well aware the Americans have been practicing in annual military exercises for years. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs appealing is that decapitation is the quickest way to terminate a conflict,‚Äù Seiler, who visited North Korea on negotiating teams before the North cut off all communications after the failure of Kim‚Äôs meetings with Trump in 2019, told the influential Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.

‚ÄúDecapitation would be helpful in trying to deter North Korea,‚Äù Seiler believes. ‚ÄúWithout Kim Jong Un,‚Äù he notes, North Korea would have no leader, no one who would know how to lead its outsized, underfed armed forces of 1.2 million troops, much less anyone in charge of its nuclear program.

Kim betrayed his deepest fears of a plot like the fracas in Caracas by authorizing release for North Korean audiences of a film all about the capture of Maduro. The film ‚ÄúDays and Nights of Confrontation,‚Äù could not have aired on North Korean state TV at a more propitious moment, days after elite U.S. troops seized Maduro and his wife. The message is clear: what‚Äôs to stop the Americans from repeating themselves in North Korea?

The film epitomizes ‚Äúthe trend of racy, Hollywood-style content aimed at appealing to young people,‚Äù says a South Korean website, NK News, that tracks North Korea. ‚ÄúSurely Mr. Kim and his family, including his fiery younger sister Yo-Jong, and his beloved teenage daughter, Ju-ae, would make great targets.‚Äù In one fell swoop the Americans could wipe out the dynasty that Kim‚Äôs grandfather, Kim Il-Sung, founded when the Soviet Union installed him as leader of the northern half of the divided Korean peninsula after the Japanese surrender in 1945.

Capturing Kim is not a new idea for American ‚Äúrendition‚Äù experts.

‚ÄúSome White House aides believed his death would paralyze his country,‚Äù writes Joel Wit, who also joined negotiating teams to North Korea, inspecting the nuclear site at Yongbyon north of Pyongyang after North Korea signed an agreement in 1994 to stop producing nukes. ‚ÄúGo get Kim Jong Un, we were postured to do that,‚Äù says Wit in his tell-all book, Fallout: The Inside Story of America‚Äôs Failure to Disarm North Korea. One official is quoted as saying: ‚ÄúEveryone, including the North Koreans, knew killing him as part of the war plan.‚Äù

Maybe the U.S. would have to marshal more than the 150 or so aircraft, and a few hundred troops, including the U.S. Army‚Äôs elite Delta Force, that were needed to grab Maduro, but Kim is well aware his family and entourage could be hustled aboard a helicopter bound for an American warship long before the Russians and Chinese could respond in support of North Korea‚Äôs military establishment, ill-fed, ill-trained and not at all ready to leap to their leader‚Äôs instant defense.

If capturing Kim sounds like mission impossible, consider his frequent appearances inspecting industrial and agricultural projects, reviewing troops, and presiding at ceremonies. He also shows up periodically at missile launches, perhaps the best time of all to catch him just as he‚Äôs making a show of pressing the button. The Americans, moreover, are steeped in the knowledge of what it will take to get him. U.S. forces have been training for years to go after him. Annual U.S.-South Korean exercises once routinely wound up with a mock ‚Äúdecapitation‚Äù of ‚Äúthe North Korean leader,‚Äù without explicitly naming Kim.

The U.S. command in Korea dropped the word ‚Äúdecapitation‚Äù from the war games in deference to their South Korean ally, who reminded them such language might not help in attempts at fruitless talks with the North Koreans, who now refuse to talk anyway. The word is gaining currency again with Maduro‚Äôs capture‚Äîwhile raising the question in Pyongyang of who might come next on the American hit list.

‚ÄúNorth Korea‚Äôs Kim expected to cling to [his] nuclear security blanket after Venezuela,‚Äù blared one headline in the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post. ‚ÄúThe United States‚Äô decapitation operation against Venezuela will reinforce North Korea‚Äôs nuclear ambitions,‚Äù read another. That warning should prompt Trump to act quickly to get rid of a nuisance who‚Äôs been plaguing the region for years with bombastic harangues, threatening his enemies with a nuclear holocaust while his own people suffer from hunger and disease.

Flights of heavy American bombers do little or nothing to remove the threats posed by America‚Äôs foes. Kim knows he can laugh off another aerial show of intimidation or a useless meeting with Trump. The threat of a Maduro-style capture is far more effective. Kim‚Äôs worst fear is that the Americans, after rehearsing ‚Äúdecapitation‚Äù for years, will decide it‚Äôs time to finally put their plan into effect, stifling Asia‚Äôs leading terrorist just as suddenly as they whisked Maduro and his wife off to jail in New York.

title: Trump would quickly replace tariffs after court action, New York Times reports
description: The administration of President Donald Trump would enact new tariffs almost immediately if the Supreme Court struck down sweeping global tariffs the president launched under an
fullText:
Jan 19 (Reuters) - The administration of President Donald Trump would enact ‚Äãnew tariffs almost immediately if the ‚ÄåSupreme Court struck down sweeping global tariffs ‚Äåthe president launched under an emergency law, U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer told the New York Times in an ‚Å†interview published ‚Äåon Monday.

The Supreme Court could rule on the tariffs in ‚Äçthe coming weeks, and possibly as early as Tuesday.

Greer said the administration would "start the ‚Äãnext day" to replace the ‚Äåtariffs with other levies, the Times reported.

The challenge to the levies being weighed at the Supreme Court marks a major test of presidential powers as ‚Å†well as of the ‚Äãcourt's willingness to ‚Äãcheck some of the Republican president's far-reaching assertions of authority since ‚Äçhe returned ‚Å†to office in January 2025.The Trade Representative's office did not immediately ‚Å†respond to a request for comment.

title: Hoping for a $2,000 tariff dividend check? Trump is giving mixed messages.
description: If you have been hoping for a $2,000 tariff rebate check, President Donald Trump gave mixed messages in a recent interview with The New York Times.
fullText:
If you have been hoping for a $2,000 tariff rebate check, it may not come.

President Donald Trump gave mixed messages about the issues in a recent interview with The New York Times.

"You've promised $2,000 checks to Americans based off of your tariff revenues. When can they expect those?" Times reporter Katie Rogers asked.

"I did do that? When did I do that?" Trump said. "Yeah, I'm thinking. Well, I did $1,776 for the military."

When Tyler Pager, another Times journalist, followed up, asking when the checks would come, Trump replied that "the tariff money is so substantial."

"That's coming in, that I'll be able to do $2,000 sometime," Trump said. "I would say toward the end of the year."

In November, Trump posted on Truth Social proposing a $2,000 payout to all US citizens with low or middle incomes, because the government is "taking in so much money" from tariffs. According to¬†a recent Supreme Court filing, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent estimated that the federal government may have collected around¬†$1 trillion in tariffs.

"People that are against Tariffs are FOOLS!" Trump posted on Truth Social on November 9. "A dividend of at least $2000 a person (not including high income people!) will be paid to everyone."

Even if the Supreme Court doesn't rule his tariffs enacted under emergency powers unconstitutional in its coming decision, revenue generated by the duties may be spread too thin for a payout to Americans.

Later in the interview with the Times, Trump said that the tariff revenue will go toward reducing federal government debt and funding national defense.

According to the Treasury, the national debt as of January is around $38.40 trillion, and rose by $2.17 trillion in 2025. If Bessent's estimate on tariff revenue is correct, the total amount collected over the past year would cover less than 50% of the increase in debt.

Trump also recently called for increasing the defense budget to $1.5 trillion for the fiscal year 2027. The Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget estimates that the move would add $5.8 trillion to the national debt over the next 10 years.

Trump has promised or suggested a number of payouts to Americans in his second term, including a $5,000 DOGE check, a $10,000 bonus for air traffic controllers with perfect attendance during the government shutdown, $1,000 to Trump Accounts for children who are citizens, and a $1,776 "warrior dividend" for active military members.

As for whether Trump even has the power to issue the checks, Congress, not the presidency, has the power of the purse and can make those appropriations.

The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

title: Trump says building a 'New York Stock Exchange' in Dallas is bad thing for New York
description: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday that building a "New York Stock Exchange" in Dallas is an "unbelievably" bad thing for New York.
fullText:
Jan 18 (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump said on Monday ‚Äãthat building a "New York Stock ‚ÄåExchange" in Dallas is an "unbelievably" bad thing ‚Äåfor New York.

"I can't believe they would let this happen. A big test for the new ‚Å†Mayor!" he ‚Äåsaid in a post on Truth Social.

Intercontinental Exchange, the ‚Äçowner of NYSE, had said it would add Texas as its venue ‚Äãfor a secondary listing last ‚Äåyear.

NYSE Texas, which officially opened for business earlier in 2025, saw 10 companies, including oilfield service company Halliburton and Truth Social-parent Trump ‚Å†Media & Technology Group, ‚Äãdual list on ‚Äãthe Dallas-based exchange in the first three months.

Intercontinental Exchange and ‚Äçthe New ‚Å†York mayor's office did not immediately respond to a request ‚Å†seeking comment.
